soln_description:
# Answer: 47.

Solution. The given equation is equivalent to the following

$$
\left(x^{3}-1\right)-8\left(x^{2}-x\right)=0 \Leftrightarrow(x-1)\left(x^{2}+x+1\right)-8 x(x-1)=0 \Leftrightarrow(x-1)\left(x^{2}-7 x+1\right)=0 \text {, }
$$

from which $x=1$ or $x=\frac{7 \pm \sqrt{45}}{2}$. The largest root is $p=\frac{7+\sqrt{45}}{2}$, and the smallest is $-q=\frac{7-\sqrt{45}}{2}$. Then

$$
\frac{p}{q}+\frac{q}{p}=\frac{7+\sqrt{45}}{7-\sqrt{45}}+\frac{7-\sqrt{45}}{7+\sqrt{45}}=\frac{(7+\sqrt{45})^{2}+(7-\sqrt{45})^{2}}{(7+\sqrt{45})(7-\sqrt{45})}=\frac{2(49+45)}{4}=47
$$
informal_statement: 2. Find the value of the expression $\frac{p}{q}+\frac{q}{p}$, where $p$ and $q$ are the largest and smallest roots of the equation $x^{3}-8 x^{2}+8 x=1$, respectively.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 2. Find the value of the expression $\frac{p}{q}+\frac{q}{p}$, where $p$ and $q$ are the largest and smallest roots of the equation $x^{3}-8 x^{2}+8 x=1$, respectively. -/
theorem algebra_145239 (p q : ℝ) (hp : p^3 - 8 * p^2 + 8 * p = 1) (hq : q^3 - 8 * q^2 + 8 * q = 1)
    (h : p > q) : p / q + q / p = 47 := by

soln_description:
3.484 .

Let the duration of the bell ringing be $60 k \mathrm{~s}$, then during this period, the number of times the first clock rings is $x=\frac{60 k}{4}+1=15 k+1$; the number of times the second clock rings is $y=\frac{60 k}{5}+1=12 k+1$; the number of times the third clock rings is $z=\frac{60 k}{6}+1=10 k+1$; the number of times the first and second clocks ring simultaneously is $\frac{60 k}{20}+1=3 k+1$; the number of times the first and third clocks ring simultaneously is $\frac{60 k}{12}+1=5 k+1$; the number of times the second and third clocks ring simultaneously is $\frac{60 k}{30}+1=2 k+1$; the number of times the first, second, and third clocks ring simultaneously is $\frac{60 k}{60}+1=k+1$. According to the problem, we have
$$
\begin{aligned}
365= & (15 k+1)+(12 k+1)+(10 k+1)- \\
& (3 k+1)-(5 k+1)-(2 k+1)+(k+1) \\
= & 28 k+1 .
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore, $k=13$.
Substituting $k$ into the expressions for $x, y, z$ we get
$$
\begin{array}{l}
x=15 k+1=196, y=12 k+1=157, \\
z=10 k+1=131 .
\end{array}
$$

Thus, $x+y+z=484$.
informal_statement: 3. A certain temple has three bronze bells, A, B, and C. Bell A rings once every $4 \mathrm{~s}$, Bell B rings once every $5 \mathrm{~s}$, and Bell C rings once every $6 \mathrm{~s}$. At the arrival of the New Year, the three bells ring simultaneously and stop ringing at the same time. A person hears a total of 365 bell rings. If during this period, Bell A, Bell B, and Bell C ring $x$ times, $y$ times, and $z$ times respectively, then $x+y+z=$ $\qquad$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 3. A certain temple has three bronze bells, A, B, and C. Bell A rings once every $4 \mathrm{~s}$, Bell B rings once every $5 \mathrm{~s}$, and Bell C rings once every $6 \mathrm{~s}$. At the arrival of the New Year, the three bells ring simultaneously and stop ringing at the same time. A person hears a total of 365 bell rings. If during this period, Bell A, Bell B, and Bell C ring $x$ times, $y$ times, and $z$ times respectively, then $x+y+z=$ $\qquad$ -/
theorem number_theory_310957 (x y z : ℕ) (h : x*4+y*5+z*6=365) :
    x+y+z=484 := by

soln_description:
Given $x \geqslant y \geqslant z > 0$, then
$$\begin{aligned}
& (x y + y z + z x)\left[\frac{1}{(x+y)^{2}} + \frac{1}{(y+z)^{2}} + \frac{1}{(z+x)^{2}}\right] - \frac{9}{4} \\
= & \frac{x y + z(x+y)}{(x+y)^{2}} + \frac{y z + x(y+z)}{(y+z)^{2}} + \frac{z x + y(z+x)}{(z+x)^{2}} - \frac{9}{4} \\
= & \frac{x}{y+z} + \frac{y}{z+x} + \frac{z}{x+y} - \frac{3}{2} + \frac{x y}{(x+y)^{2}} - \frac{1}{4} + \frac{y z}{(y+z)^{2}} - \frac{1}{4} \\
& + \frac{z x}{(z+x)^{2}} - \frac{1}{4} \\
= & \frac{1}{2}\left[\frac{(x-y)^{2}}{(y+z)(z+x)} + \frac{(z-x)^{2}}{(x+y)(y+z)} + \frac{(y-z)^{2}}{(x+y)(z+x)}\right] \\
& - \left[\frac{(x-y)^{2}}{4(x+y)^{2}} + \frac{(y-z)^{2}}{4(y+z)^{2}} + \frac{(z-x)^{2}}{4(z+x)^{2}}\right] \\
= & \frac{1}{4}\left\{\left[\frac{2}{(y+z)(z+x)} - \frac{1}{(x+y)^{2}}\right](x-y)^{2}\right. \\
& + \left[\frac{2}{(x+y)(z+x)} - \frac{1}{(y+z)^{2}}\right](y-z)^{2} \\
& \left. + \left[\frac{2}{(x+y)(y+z)} - \frac{1}{(z+x)^{2}}\right](z-x)^{2}\right\} \\
& = \frac{1}{4}\left[S_{z}(x-y)^{2} + S_{x}(y-z)^{2} + S_{y}(z-x)^{2}\right]
\end{aligned}$$

where $S_{x} = \frac{2}{(y+z)(z+x)} - \frac{1}{(x+y)^{2}}, S_{x} = \frac{2}{(x+y)(z+x)} - \frac{1}{(y+z)^{2}}$,
$$S_{y} = \frac{2}{(x+y)(y+z)} - \frac{1}{(z+x)^{2}} .$$

Since $x \geqslant y \geqslant z > 0$, we have
$$2(x+y)^{2} > (x+y)^{2} > (y+z)(z+x)$$

which implies $S_{z} > 0$. Also,
$$2(z+x)^{2} - (x+y)(y+z) = (x^{2} - x y) + (x^{2} - y z) + 2 z^{2} + 3 z x > 0,$$
so $S_{y} \geqslant 0$.
If $S_{x} \geqslant 0$, the right-hand side of (1) is $\geqslant 0$, and the inequality is proved.
If $S_{x} < 0$, then $S_{y} > 0$, so $\frac{y}{x} \geqslant \frac{y-z}{x-z} \geqslant 0$, thus
$$\begin{aligned}
(y-z)^{2} & \leqslant \left(\frac{y}{x}\right)^{2}(x-z)^{2} \\
S_{x}(y-z)^{2} + S_{y}(z-x)^{2} & \geqslant S_{x}\left(\frac{y}{x}\right)^{2}(x-z)^{2} + S_{y}(z-x)^{2} \\
& = \frac{y^{2} S_{x} + x^{2} S_{y}}{x^{2}}(z-x)^{2}
\end{aligned}$$

We now prove $y^{2} S_{x} + x^{2} S_{y} \geqslant 0$. In fact,
$$\begin{aligned}
& (x+y)(y+z)^{2}(z+x)^{2}\left(y^{2} S_{x} + x^{2} S_{y}\right) \\
= & y^{2}\left[2(y+z)^{2}(z+x) - (x+y)(z+x)^{2}\right] + x^{2}[2(y+z)(z+ \\
& x)^{2} - (x+y)(y+z)^{2}] \\
= & y^{2}\left(2 y^{2} z + x y^{2} + 3 y z^{2} + 2 x y z + 2 z^{3} + x z^{2} - 2 z x^{2} - x^{3}\right) \\
& + x^{2}\left(2 y z^{2} + x^{2} y + 3 x z^{2} + 2 x y z + 2 z^{3} + x^{2} z - 2 z y^{2} - y^{3}\right) \\
= & 2 x y z\left(x^{2} + y^{2} - 2 x y\right) + x y\left(x^{3} + y^{3} - x^{2} y - x y^{2}\right) + y^{2}\left(2 y^{2} z\right. \\
& \left. + 3 y z^{2} + 2 z^{3} + x z^{2}\right) + x^{2}\left(2 y z^{2} + 3 x z^{2} + z^{3} + x^{2} z\right) \\
= & 2 x y z(x-y)^{2} + x y(x+y)(x-y)^{2} + y^{2}\left(2 y^{2} z + 3 y z^{2}\right. \\
& \left. + 2 z^{3} + x z^{2}\right) + x^{2}\left(2 y z^{2} + 3 x z^{2} + z^{3} + x^{2} z\right) > 0 .
\end{aligned}$$

Therefore, the right-hand side of (2) is $\geqslant 0$, so
$$S_{z}(x-y)^{2} + S_{x}(y-z)^{2} + S_{y}(z-x)^{2} \geqslant 0$$

In conclusion, the original inequality is proved.
informal_statement: $\square$ Example 9 Let $x, y, z$ be positive real numbers, prove that: $(x y+y z+z x)\left[\frac{1}{(x+y)^{2}}+\right.$ $\left.\frac{1}{(y+z)^{2}}+\frac{1}{(z+x)^{2}}\right] \geqslant \frac{9}{4} .$(1996 Iranian Mathematical Olympiad)
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- $\square$ Example 9 Let $x, y, z$ be positive real numbers, prove that: $(x y+y z+z x)\left[\frac{1}{(x+y)^{2}}+\right.$ $\left.\frac{1}{(y+z)^{2}}+\frac{1}{(z+x)^{2}}\right] \geqslant \frac{9}{4} .$(1996 Iranian Mathematical Olympiad) -/
theorem inequalities_598898 (x y z : ℝ) (hx : 0 < x) (hy : 0 < y) (hz : 0 < z) :
    (x * y + y * z + z * x) * ((1 / (x + y) ^ 2) + (1 / (y + z) ^ 2) + (1 / (z + x) ^ 2)) ≥ 9 / 4 := by

soln_description:
SolUtion
From the first equation, we have $x^{2}=1+2 x y$
Substituting this into the second equation, we obtain $5(1+2 x y)-2 x y+2 y^{2}=5$, which simplifies to $y^{2}+4 x y=0$

Factorising, we have $y(y+4 x)=0$, and so $y=0$ or $y=-4 x$
If $y=0$ we have, from the first equation, $x= \pm 1$
If $y=-4 x$ we have, from the first equation, $x= \pm \frac{1}{3}$
So there are four solutions, namely
$$
(x, y)=(1,0),(-1,0),\left(\frac{1}{3},-\frac{4}{3}\right),\left(-\frac{1}{3}, \frac{4}{3}\right)
$$
informal_statement:
1. Solve the pair of simultaneous equations
$$
\begin{aligned}
x^{2}-2 x y & =1, \\
5 x^{2}-2 x y+2 y^{2} & =5 .
\end{aligned}
$$
informal_proof:
**
We want to prove that two statements are equivalent: first, that a given system of two equations holds, and second, that \((x, y)\) is one of four specific pairs of real numbers. We will prove this by showing both directions of the equivalence.

**Part 1: Forward Direction (If the equations hold, then \((x, y)\) is one of the four solutions)**

Assume that \(x\) and \(y\) are real numbers satisfying the following system of equations:
1.  \(x^2 - 2xy = 1\)
2.  \(5x^2 - 2xy + 2y^2 = 5\)

Our goal is to show that \((x, y)\) must be one of the four specified pairs.

First, we can manipulate these equations to derive a simpler one. From equation (1), we can express \(2xy\) as \(x^2 - 1\). Substitute this into equation (2):
\(5x^2 - (x^2 - 1) + 2y^2 = 5\)
Simplify the expression:
\(4x^2 + 1 + 2y^2 = 5\)
Subtract 1 from both sides:
\(4x^2 + 2y^2 = 4\)
Divide by 2:
3.  \(2x^2 + y^2 = 2\)

Now, we will use equation (1) and equation (3) to find a crucial relationship between \(x\) and \(y\). Multiply equation (1) by 2:
\(2(x^2 - 2xy) = 2(1)\)
\(2x^2 - 4xy = 2\)
Subtract this new equation from equation (3):
\((2x^2 + y^2) - (2x^2 - 4xy) = 2 - 2\)
Simplify the left side:
\(y^2 + 4xy = 0\)
Factor out \(y\):
\(y(y + 4x) = 0\)

This equation tells us that either \(y = 0\) or \(y + 4x = 0\). We consider these two cases:

**Case 1: \(y = 0\)**
Substitute \(y = 0\) back into the original equation (1):
\(x^2 - 2x(0) = 1\)
\(x^2 = 1\)
This implies that \(x\) must be either \(1\) or \(-1\).
*   If \(x = 1\) and \(y = 0\), we have the solution \((1, 0)\).
*   If \(x = -1\) and \(y = 0\), we have the solution \((-1, 0)\).

**Case 2: \(y + 4x = 0\)**
This equation can be rewritten as \(y = -4x\).
Substitute \(y = -4x\) back into the original equation (1):
\(x^2 - 2x(-4x) = 1\)
\(x^2 + 8x^2 = 1\)
\(9x^2 = 1\)
Divide by 9:
\(x^2 = 1/9\)
This implies that \(x\) must be either \(1/3\) or \(-1/3\).
*   If \(x = 1/3\): Substitute this value into \(y = -4x\): \(y = -4(1/3) = -4/3\). This gives the solution \((1/3, -4/3)\).
*   If \(x = -1/3\): Substitute this value into \(y = -4x\): \(y = -4(-1/3) = 4/3\). This gives the solution \((-1/3, 4/3)\).

Combining both cases, we have shown that if \(x\) and \(y\) satisfy the given system of equations, then \((x, y)\) must be one of the four pairs: \((1, 0)\), \((-1, 0)\), \((1/3, -4/3)\), or \((-1/3, 4/3)\).

**Part 2: Backward Direction (If \((x, y)\) is one of the four solutions, then the equations hold)**

Now, we assume that \((x, y)\) is one of the four specified solution pairs, and we will verify that both original equations are satisfied for each pair.

**1. Consider the solution \((x, y) = (1, 0)\):**
*   For equation (1): \(1^2 - 2(1)(0) = 1 - 0 = 1\). This holds true.
*   For equation (2): \(5(1)^2 - 2(1)(0) + 2(0)^2 = 5 - 0 + 0 = 5\). This holds true.

**2. Consider the solution \((x, y) = (-1, 0)\):**
*   For equation (1): \((-1)^2 - 2(-1)(0) = 1 - 0 = 1\). This holds true.
*   For equation (2): \(5(-1)^2 - 2(-1)(0) + 2(0)^2 = 5 - 0 + 0 = 5\). This holds true.

**3. Consider the solution \((x, y) = (1/3, -4/3)\):**
*   For equation (1): \((1/3)^2 - 2(1/3)(-4/3) = 1/9 - (-8/9) = 1/9 + 8/9 = 9/9 = 1\). This holds true.
*   For equation (2): \(5(1/3)^2 - 2(1/3)(-4/3) + 2(-4/3)^2 = 5(1/9) - (-8/9) + 2(16/9) = 5/9 + 8/9 + 32/9 = (5+8+32)/9 = 45/9 = 5\). This holds true.

**4. Consider the solution \((x, y) = (-1/3, 4/3)\):**
*   For equation (1): \((-1/3)^2 - 2(-1/3)(4/3) = 1/9 - (-8/9) = 1/9 + 8/9 = 9/9 = 1\). This holds true.
*   For equation (2): \(5(-1/3)^2 - 2(-1/3)(4/3) + 2(4/3)^2 = 5(1/9) - (-8/9) + 2(16/9) = 5/9 + 8/9 + 32/9 = (5+8+32)/9 = 45/9 = 5\). This holds true.

In all four cases, both original equations are satisfied.

**Conclusion**
Since we have proven both directions of the equivalence, we conclude that the system of equations \(x^2 - 2xy = 1\) and \(5x^2 - 2xy + 2y^2 = 5\) holds if and only if \((x, y)\) is one of the four pairs: \((1, 0)\), \((-1, 0)\), \((1/3, -4/3)\), or \((-1/3, 4/3)\).
**
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 1. Solve the pair of simultaneous equations
$$
\begin{aligned}
x^{2}-2 x y & =1, \\
5 x^{2}-2 x y+2 y^{2} & =5 .
\end{aligned}
$$ -/
theorem algebra_237851 (x y : ℝ) :
    x^2 - 2 * x * y = 1 ∧ 5 * x^2 - 2 * x * y + 2 * y^2 = 5 ↔
    (x = 1 ∧ y = 0) ∨ (x = -1 ∧ y = 0) ∨ (x = 1 / 3 ∧ y = -4 / 3) ∨ (x = -1 / 3 ∧ y = 4 / 3) := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_237851 (x y : ℝ) :
    x^2 - 2 * x * y = 1 ∧ 5 * x^2 - 2 * x * y + 2 * y^2 = 5 ↔
    (x = 1 ∧ y = 0) ∨ (x = -1 ∧ y = 0) ∨ (x = 1 / 3 ∧ y = -4 / 3) ∨ (x = -1 / 3 ∧ y = 4 / 3) := by 
  constructor
  · -- Forward direction: both equations hold implies the four solutions
    rintro ⟨h₁, h₂⟩
    
    have h₃ : 2 * x^2 + y^2 = 2 := by 
      nlinarith
  
    have h5 : (y) * (y + 4 * x) = 0 := by
      nlinarith [sq_nonneg (x * 3 - 1), sq_nonneg (x * 3 + 1), sq_nonneg (y + 4 * x), sq_nonneg (y - 0), sq_nonneg (x^2 - 1/9), sq_nonneg (x^2 - 1)]
  
    cases' (mul_eq_zero.mp h5) with hy1 hy2
  
    · -- Case 1: y = 0
      have h6 : x^2 = 1 := by 
        rw [hy1] at h₁
        nlinarith
  
      have hx1 : x = 1 ∨ x = -1 := by 
        rw [sq_eq_one_iff] at h6
        exact h6
  
      cases' hx1 with hx1 hx1
  
      · -- Subcase 1: x = 1, y = 0
        left 
        exact ⟨hx1, by linarith⟩ 
      · -- Subcase 2: x = -1, y = 0 
        right 
        left 
        exact ⟨hx1, by linarith⟩ 
    · -- Case 2: y + 4x = 0 
      have hy_eq : y = -4 * x := by 
        linarith
  
      have hx2 : x^2 = 1 / 9 := by 
        rw [hy_eq] at h₁ 
        nlinarith
  
      have hx3 : x = 1 / 3 ∨ x = -1 / 3 := by 
        have h1 : x^2 - (1/9) = 0 := by 
          linarith [hx2]
        have h2 : (x - 1/3) * (x + 1/3) = 0 := by 
          nlinarith
        cases' (mul_eq_zero.mp h2) with h3 h4
        · -- x - 1/3 = 0 => x = 1/3
          left 
          linarith 
        · -- x + 1/3 = 0 => x = -1/3 
          right 
          linarith 
      cases' hx3 with hx3 hx3
      · -- x = 1/3
        have hy3 : y = -4 / 3 := by 
          rw [hx3] at hy_eq 
          nlinarith 
        right 
        right 
        left 
        exact ⟨hx3, hy3⟩ 
      · -- x = -1/3 
        have hy3 : y = 4 / 3 := by 
          rw [hx3] at hy_eq 
          nlinarith 
        right 
        right 
        right 
        exact ⟨hx3, hy3⟩ 
  · -- Backward direction: the four solutions satisfy both equations 
    rintro (h | h | h | h)
    
    · -- (1, 0)
      rcases h with ⟨rfl, rfl⟩ 
      constructor
      · -- Equation 1
        norm_num 
      · -- Equation 2
        norm_num 
    · -- (-1, 0)
      rcases h with ⟨rfl, rfl⟩ 
      constructor
      · -- Equation 1
        norm_num 
      · -- Equation 2
        norm_num 
    · -- (1/3, -4/3)
      rcases h with ⟨rfl, rfl⟩ 
      constructor
      · -- Equation 1
        norm_num 
      · -- Equation 2
        norm_num 
    · -- (-1/3, 4/3)
      rcases h with ⟨rfl, rfl⟩ 
      constructor
      · -- Equation 1
        norm_num 
      · -- Equation 2
        norm_num

soln_description: Solution. The general term in the binomial expansion is $T_{k+1}=\binom{100}{k} 3^{\frac{100-k}{2}} 2^{\frac{k}{3}}$, $k \in\{0,1, \ldots, 100\}$. For the term to be rational, $\frac{100-k}{2}$ and $\frac{k}{3}$ must be integers. Since $\frac{100-k}{2}$ is an integer if 2 is a divisor of $k$, and $\frac{k}{3}$ is an integer if 3 is a divisor of $k$, we get that $k$ must be an integer divisible by 6. Therefore, the number of rational terms is the number of integers divisible by 6 from 0 to 100, which is $\left[\frac{100}{6}\right]+1=17$.
informal_statement: 2. How many rational terms are there in the expansion of the binomial $(\sqrt{3}+\sqrt[3]{2})^{100}$?
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 2. How many rational terms are there in the expansion of the binomial $(\sqrt{3}+\sqrt[3]{2})^{100}$? -/
theorem algebra_251536 : {x : ℚ | ∃ n : ℕ, x = (Nat.choose 100 n) * (2 ^ ((1 : ℝ) / 3)) ^ (100 - n) * (Real.sqrt 3) ^ n}.ncard = 17 := by

informal_statement:
## Task Condition

Find the derivative.

$y=\frac{\sqrt{2 x+3}(x-2)}{x^{2}}$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- ## Task Condition

Find the derivative.

$y=\frac{\sqrt{2 x+3}(x-2)}{x^{2}}$ -/
theorem calculus_136255 {f : ℝ → ℝ} (hf : f = fun x => sqrt (2 * x + 3) * (x - 2) / x ^ 2) :
    deriv f = fun x => (-x ^ 2 + 3 * x + 12) / (x ^ 3 * sqrt (2 * x + 3)) := by

informal_statement:
Let $a$, $b$, and $c$ be real numbers such that $abc + 10 = 6a + 3b + 2c$. Prove that:
\[
(a^2 + 1)(b^2 + 4)(c^2 + 9) \geq 100
\]
formal_statement:
import Mathlib
open Real

/- Let $a$, $b$, and $c$ be real numbers such that $abc + 10 = 6a + 3b + 2c$. Prove that:
\[
(a^2 + 1)(b^2 + 4)(c^2 + 9) \geq 100
\] -/
theorem inequalities_3453 {a b c : ℝ} (h : a * b * c + 10 = 6 * a + 3 * b + 2 * c) : (a ^ 2 + 1) * (b ^ 2 + 4) * (c ^ 2 + 9) ≥ 100 := by

soln_description:
In the set, three of the numbers are greater than or equal to 3 , and two of the numbers are less than 3 .

The smallest number must be one of the numbers that is less than 3 , that is, 2.3 or 2.23 .

Of these two numbers, 2.23 is the smallest, so is the smallest number in the set.

ANSWER: (D)
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- The smallest number in the set $\{3.2,2.3,3,2.23,3.22\}$ is
(A) 3.2
(B) 2.3
(C) 3
(D) 2.23
(E) 3.22 -/
theorem number_theory_282972 : min (min (min (min 3.2 2.3) 3) 2.23) 3.22 = 2.23 := by

soln_description: If we simply write out a 4n = (1 - 1/2 + 1/3 - 1/4 + ... - 1/4n) and a 2n /2 = (1/2 - 1/4 + 1/6 - 1/8 + ... - 1/4n) and add term by term we find that a 4n + a 2n /2 = b 3n . Taking the limit, we have immediately that h = 3k/2. But clearly k > 0, since if we group the terms in pairs, each pair is positive. Hence h ≠ k. 14th Putnam 1954 © John Scholes jscholes@kalva.demon.co.uk 26 Nov 1999
informal_statement: 14th Putnam 1954 Problem B2 Let a n = ∑ 1 n (-1) i+1 /i. Assume that lim n→∞ a n = k. Rearrange the terms by taking two positive terms, then one negative term, then another two positive terms, then another negative term and so on. Let b n be the sum of the first n terms of the rearranged series. Assume that lim n→∞ b n = h. Show that b 3n = a 4n + a 2n /2, and hence that h ≠ k.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Topology Filter Real Complex TopologicalSpace Finset
open scoped BigOperators

/- 14th Putnam 1954 Problem B2 Let a n = ∑ 1 n (-1) i+1 /i. Assume that lim n→∞ a n = k. Rearrange the terms by taking two positive terms, then one negative term, then another two positive terms, then another negative term and so on. Let b n be the sum of the first n terms of the rearranged series. Assume that lim n→∞ b n = h. Show that b 3n = a 4n + a 2n /2, and hence that h ≠ k. -/
theorem calculus_140605 {a b : ℕ → ℝ}
  (ha : ∀ n, a n = ∑ i in Icc 1 n, (-1 : ℝ)^i / i)
  (hb : ∀ n, b n = ∑ i in Icc 1 n, (-1 : ℝ)^i * a (2 * i - 1) * a (2 * i))
  (k h : ℝ)
  (hk : Tendsto a atTop (𝓝 k))
  (hh : Tendsto b atTop (𝓝 h)) :
  ∀ n, b (3 * n) = a (4 * n) + a (2 * n) / 2 ∧ h ≠ k :=

soln_description:
【Analysis】The problem only provides the condition of parallelism, analogous to a spatial rectangular coordinate system, we can choose a set of basis vectors $\overrightarrow{A B}$, $\overrightarrow{A D}$, and $\overrightarrow{A E}$.
Proof Let $\overrightarrow{A B}=\boldsymbol{b}, \overrightarrow{A D}=\boldsymbol{d}, \overrightarrow{A E}=e$. Then
$$
\begin{array}{l}
(|\boldsymbol{b}|+|\boldsymbol{d}|+|\boldsymbol{e}|)^{2}-|\boldsymbol{b}+\boldsymbol{d}+\boldsymbol{e}|^{2} \\
=2\left(\sum|\boldsymbol{b}||\boldsymbol{d}|-\sum|\boldsymbol{b} \cdot \boldsymbol{d}|\right) \\
=\sum\left((|b|+|\boldsymbol{d}|)^{2}-|\boldsymbol{b}+\boldsymbol{d}|^{2}\right) \\
=\sum(|\boldsymbol{b}|+|\boldsymbol{d}|+|\boldsymbol{b}+\boldsymbol{d}|)(|\boldsymbol{b}|+|\boldsymbol{d}|-|\boldsymbol{b}+\boldsymbol{d}|),
\end{array}
$$

where $\sum$ denotes the cyclic sum.
Notice that, $|\boldsymbol{b}|+|\boldsymbol{d}| \geqslant|\boldsymbol{b}+\boldsymbol{d}|$,
$$
\begin{array}{l}
|b|+|d|+|b+d| \\
\leqslant|b|+|d|+|e|+|b+d+e|
\end{array}
$$

and its cyclic permutations.
$$
\begin{array}{l} 
\text { Hence }\left(\sum|b|\right)^{2}-\left|\sum b\right|^{2} \\
\leqslant\left(\sum|b|+\left|\sum b\right|\right) \cdot \\
\sum(|b|+|d|-|b+d|) \\
\Rightarrow \sum|b|-\left|\sum b\right| \\
\leqslant 2 \sum|b|-\sum|b+d| \\
\Rightarrow \sum|b+d| \leqslant \sum|b|+\left|\sum b\right| \\
\Rightarrow|\overrightarrow{A C}|+|\overrightarrow{A H}|+|\overrightarrow{A F}| \\
\leqslant|\overrightarrow{A B}|+|\overrightarrow{A D}|+|\overrightarrow{A E}|+|\overrightarrow{A G}|,
\end{array}
$$

The equality holds if and only if the vectors $b$, $d$, and $e$ are collinear.
informal_statement:
Example 1 In the parallelepiped $A B C D E F G H$, $A E$ $/ / B F / / C G / / D H$. Prove:
$$
A F+A H+A C \leqslant A B+A D+A E+A G,
$$

and find the condition for equality.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real
open scoped BigOperators

/- Example 1 In the parallelepiped $A B C D E F G H$, $A E$ $/ / B F / / C G / / D H$. Prove:
$$
A F+A H+A C \leqslant A B+A D+A E+A G,
$$

and find the condition for equality. -/
theorem inequalities_114248 (A B C D E F G H : EuclideanSpace ℝ (Fin 3))
  (h₀ : A ≠ B) (h₁ : A ≠ C) (h₂ : A ≠ D) (h₃ : B ≠ C) (h₄ : B ≠ D)
  (h₅ : C ≠ D) (h₆ : E ≠ F) (h₇ : E ≠ G) (h₈ : E ≠ H) (h₉ : F ≠ G)
  (h₁₀ : F ≠ H) (h₁₁ : G ≠ H) (h₁₂ : dist A E = dist B F) (h₁₃ : dist B F = dist C G)
  (h₁₄ : dist C G = dist D H) :
  dist A F + dist A H + dist A C ≤ dist A B + dist A D + dist A E + dist A G ∧
  (dist A F + dist A H + dist A C = dist A B + dist A D + dist A E + dist A G ↔
    (convexHull ℝ {A, B, C, D, E, F, G, H} = convexHull ℝ {A, B, C, D} ∪ convexHull ℝ {E, F, G, H})) :=

soln_description:
17. Given $|w|=1$, we can set $w=\cos \theta + \mathrm{i} \sin \theta$, thus $\left(\frac{1+\mathrm{i} x}{1-\mathrm{i} x}\right)^{n}=\cos \theta + \mathrm{i} \sin \theta$.

Therefore, $\frac{1+\mathrm{i} x}{1-\mathrm{i} x}=\cos \frac{\theta+2 k \pi}{n} + \mathrm{i} \sin \frac{\theta+2 k \pi}{n} \quad (k=0,1,2, \cdots, n-1)$. Applying the theorem of the ratio of sums and differences, we get
$$
\begin{aligned}
-\mathrm{i} x & =\frac{1-\cos \frac{\theta+2 k \pi}{n} - \mathrm{i} \sin \frac{\theta+2 k \pi}{n}}{1+\cos \frac{\theta+2 k \pi}{n} + \mathrm{i} \sin \frac{\theta+2 k \pi}{n}} \\
x & =\frac{2 \sin ^{2} \frac{\theta+2 k \pi}{2 n} - 2 \mathrm{i} \sin \frac{\theta+2 k \pi}{2 n} \cos \frac{\theta+2 k \pi}{2 n}}{2 \cos ^{2} \frac{\theta+2 k \pi}{2 n} + 2 \mathrm{i} \sin \frac{\theta+2 k \pi}{2 n} \cos \frac{\theta+2 k \pi}{2 n}} \\
& =\tan \frac{\theta+2 k \pi}{2 n} \cdot \frac{\mathrm{i} \sin \frac{\theta+2 k \pi}{2 n} + \cos \frac{\theta+2 k \pi}{2 n}}{\cos \frac{\theta+2 k \pi}{2 n} + \mathrm{i} \sin \frac{\theta+2 k \pi}{2 n}} \\
& =\tan \frac{\theta+2 k \pi}{2 n} .
\end{aligned}
$$

By setting $k=0,1,2, \cdots, n-1$, we can obtain the $n$ distinct real roots of the original equation: $\tan \frac{\theta}{2 n}, \tan \frac{\theta+2 \pi}{2 n}, \cdots$,
$$
\tan \frac{\theta+2(n-1) \pi}{2 n}
$$
informal_statement: 17. If the complex number $|w|=1$, prove: the equation $\left(\frac{1+\mathrm{i} x}{1-\mathrm{i} x}\right)^{n}=w\left(n \in \mathbf{N}^{*}\right)$ has all distinct real roots.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 17. If the complex number $|w|=1$, prove: the equation $\left(\frac{1+\mathrm{i} x}{1-\mathrm{i} x}\right)^{n}=w\left(n \in \mathbf{N}^{*}\right)$ has all distinct real roots. -/
theorem algebra_201331 (w : ℂ) (hw : Complex.abs w = 1) (n : ℕ) (hn : n > 0) :
    {x : ℝ | ((1 + Complex.I * x) / (1 - Complex.I * x))^n = w}.encard = n := by

soln_description:
Analyzing how to transform the system of equations is one of the key points of this problem.
Proof: By adding the two equations and adding 1 to both sides, we get $\left(x^{3}+y+1\right)^{2}+z^{9}=147^{157}+157^{147}+1$. (1) We prove that both sides of (1) are not congruent modulo 19.
By Fermat's Little Theorem, if $(a, 19)=1$, then $a^{18} \equiv 1(\bmod 19)$, so $\left(z^{9}\right)^{2} \equiv 0,1(\bmod 19)$, which means $z^{9} \equiv-1$, $0,1(\bmod 19)$ (2); while the remainder of a perfect square divided by 19 is $-8,-3,-2,0,1,4,5,6,7,9$ (3), and finally by Fermat's Little Theorem $147^{157}+157^{147}+1 \equiv 14(\bmod 19)$.

By verifying (1) using (2) and (3), the remainder of the left side of (1) modulo 19 cannot be 14, therefore (1) has no integer solutions, which means the original equation has no integer solutions.
informal_statement: Example G Proof: The system of equations $\left\{\begin{array}{l}x^{6}+x^{3}+x^{3} y+y=147^{157} \\ x^{3}+x^{3} y+y^{2}+y+z^{9}=157^{1177}\end{array}\right.$ has no integer solutions.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Example G Proof: The system of equations $\left\{\begin{array}{l}x^{6}+x^{3}+x^{3} y+y=147^{157} \\ x^{3}+x^{3} y+y^{2}+y+z^{9}=157^{1177}\end{array}\right.$ has no integer solutions. -/
theorem algebra_106171 (x y z : ℤ) :
    x^6 + x^3 + x^3 * y + y = 147^157 ∧ x^3 + x^3 * y + y^2 + y + z^9 = 157^1177 → False := by

soln_description:
4. Consider the conditions that the lucky positive integer triplet $(a, b, c)$ must satisfy.
Let $m$ be a positive integer, and $\alpha, \beta, \gamma$ be non-negative integers such that
$a-1=m^{\alpha}$,
$a b-12=m^{\beta}$,
$a b c-2015=m^{\nu}$.
(1) $m$ is even.
Otherwise, from equation (1), $a$ is even. Thus, the left side of equation (2) is even, but the right side is odd, which is a contradiction.
Therefore, $m$ is even.
(2) $\gamma=0$.
Otherwise, from equation (3),
$a b c=2015+m^{\nu}$ (odd).
Hence, $a b$ is odd.
From equation (2),
$m^{\beta}=a b-12$ (odd).
Since $m$ is even, it can only be that $a b-12=1$, i.e., $a b=13$.
From equation (1), $a>1$.
Therefore, $a=13$.
Thus, $m^{\alpha}=a-1=12 \Rightarrow m=12$.
At this point, from equation (3),
$12^{\gamma}=a b c-2015=13(c-155)$,

which is impossible.
Therefore, $\gamma=0$ must hold.
Thus, $a b c=2016$.
(3) $\alpha=0$.
Otherwise, from equation (1), $a$ is an odd number greater than 1, and from equation (4), $a$ is a divisor of 2016.
Note that, $2016=2^{5} \times 3^{2} \times 7$.
Then $a$ can only be $3, 7, 9, 21, 63$.
For the cases $a=3,9,21,63$, $3 \mid a$.
Hence, $3 \mid (a b-12)$.
From equation (2), $3 \mid m$.
But from equation (1), we also have
$$
m^{\alpha}=a-1 \equiv 2(\bmod 3),
$$

which is a contradiction.
For the case $a=7$, from equation (1),
$$
m^{\alpha}=a-1=6 \Rightarrow m=6 .
$$

At this point, equation (2) becomes
$$
7 b-12=6^{\beta} \equiv \pm 1(\bmod 7),
$$

which is a contradiction.
Thus, $\alpha=0$ must hold.
Therefore, $a=2$.
From equation (4), $b c=1008$.
At this point, equation (2) becomes
$2 b-12=m^{\beta}$.
Therefore, $b>6$.
Conversely, when $b>6$, there exists a positive even number $m=2 b-12$ and a positive integer $\beta=1$ that satisfy equation (5).

The above shows that the positive integer triplet $(a, b, c)$ is lucky if and only if
$a=2, b c=1008$, and $b>6$.
Note that, the number of positive divisors of $1008=2^{4} \times 3^{2} \times 7$ is $(4+1) \times(2+1) \times(1+1)=30$, among which, the positive divisors not greater than 6 are $1,2,3,4,6$.

Thus, the number of values $b$ can take is $30-5=25$. Accordingly, the number of lucky positive integer triplets $(a, b, c)$ is 25.
informal_statement:
For each positive integer $n$, define the set
$$
P_{n}=\left\{n^{k} \mid k=0,1, \cdots\right\} \text {. }
$$

For positive integers $a$, $b$, and $c$, if there exists a positive integer $m$ such that the numbers $a-1$, $ab-12$, and $abc-2015$ (not necessarily distinct) all belong to the set $P_{m}$, then the positive integer triplet $(a, b, c)$ is called "lucky". Find the number of all lucky positive integer triplets.
（Supplied by He Yijie）
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

def P (n : ℕ) := {x | ∃ k, x = n ^ k}

def isLucky (a b c : ℕ) :=
  ∃ m, 0 < m ∧ a - 1 ∈ P m ∧ b * a - 12 ∈ P m ∧ a * b * c - 2015 ∈ P m

/- For each positive integer $n$, define the set
$$
P_{n}=\left\{n^{k} \mid k=0,1, \cdots\right\} \text {. }
$$

For positive integers $a$, $b$, and $c$, if there exists a positive integer $m$ such that the numbers $a-1$, $ab-12$, and $abc-2015$ (not necessarily distinct) all belong to the set $P_{m}$, then the positive integer triplet $(a, b, c)$ is called "lucky". Find the number of all lucky positive integer triplets.
（Supplied by He Yijie） -/
theorem number_theory_311951 :
    {(a, b, c) : ℕ × ℕ × ℕ | 0 < a ∧ 0 < b ∧ 0 < c ∧ isLucky a b c}.ncard = 25 := by

informal_statement: Let $n \in \mathbb{N}$ and $\theta \in \mathbb{R}$. Prove that $(1+2\sin^2\theta)^n + (1+2\cos^2\theta)^n \ge 2^{n+1}$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set

/- Let $n \in \mathbb{N}$ and $\theta \in \mathbb{R}$. Prove that $(1+2\sin^2\theta)^n + (1+2\cos^2\theta)^n \ge 2^{n+1}$. -/
theorem inequalities_2193 (n : ℕ) (θ : ℝ) :
  (1 + 2 * sin θ ^ 2) ^ n + (1 + 2 * cos θ ^ 2) ^ n ≥ 2 ^ (n + 1) := by

informal_statement: 24. [12] Define a sequence of polynomials as follows: let $a_{1}=3 x^{2}-x$, let $a_{2}=3 x^{2}-7 x+3$, and for $n \geq 1$, let $a_{n+2}=\frac{5}{2} a_{n+1}-a_{n}$. As $n$ tends to infinity, what is the limit of the sum of the roots of $a_{n}$ ?
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Topology Filter Real Complex TopologicalSpace Finset
open scoped BigOperators

/- 24. [12] Define a sequence of polynomials as follows: let $a_{1}=3 x^{2}-x$, let $a_{2}=3 x^{2}-7 x+3$, and for $n \geq 1$, let $a_{n+2}=\frac{5}{2} a_{n+1}-a_{n}$. As $n$ tends to infinity, what is the limit of the sum of the roots of $a_{n}$ ? -/
theorem algebra_157438 (a : ℕ → ℝ → ℝ)
  (h₀ : ∀ x, a 1 x = 3 * x ^ 2 - x)
  (h₁ : ∀ x, a 2 x = 3 * x ^ 2 - 7 * x + 3)
  (h₂ : ∀ n ≥ 1, ∀ x, a (n + 2) x = (5 / 2) * a (n + 1) x - a n x) :
  Tendsto (λ n => ∑ i in range n, (a (i + 1) (13 / 3)) / (a (i + 1) (13 / 3) - 1)) atTop (𝓝 (13 / 3)) :=

soln_description:
Proof: (1) Note that $k!(p-k)!\mathrm{C}_{p}^{k}=p$ ! and when $1 \leqslant k \leqslant p-1$, $(p, k!)=(p,(p-k)!)$ $=1$, we know
$$
p \mid \mathrm{C}_{p}^{k}(1 \leqslant k \leqslant p-1) .
$$

Thus, $p^{2} \mid\left(\mathrm{C}_{p}^{k}\right)^{2}(1 \leqslant k \leqslant p-1)$.
Therefore, $p^{2} \mid \sum_{k=1}^{p-1}\left(\mathrm{C}_{p}^{k}\right)^{2}$.
(2) Consider the identity
$$
(1+x)^{2 p}=(1+x)^{p}(1+x)^{p} \text {. }
$$

By the binomial theorem, we have
$$
\sum_{k=0}^{2 p} \mathrm{C}_{2 p}^{k} x^{k}=\left(\sum_{k=0}^{p} \mathrm{C}_{p}^{k} x^{k}\right)\left(\sum_{k=0}^{p} \mathrm{C}_{p}^{k} x^{k}\right) \text {. }
$$

Comparing the coefficients of $x^{p}$ on both sides, we get
$\mathrm{C}_{2 p}^{p}=\sum_{k=0}^{p} \mathrm{C}_{p}^{k} \mathrm{C}_{p}^{p-k}=\sum_{k=0}^{p}\left(\mathrm{C}_{p}^{k}\right)^{2}$.
Thus, $\sum_{k=1}^{p-1}\left(\mathrm{C}_{p}^{k}\right)^{2}=\mathrm{C}_{2 p}^{p}-2$.
Next, we prove a lemma.
Lemma: Let the $k$-element symmetric sum be
$$
\sigma_{k}=\sum_{1 \leqslant i_{1}<\cdots<i_{k} \leqslant p-1} i_{1} i_{2} \cdots i_{k}(1 \leqslant k \leqslant p-1) .
$$

Then $p \mid \sigma_{k}(1 \leqslant k<p-1)$.
Proof of the lemma: Let
$$
\begin{array}{l}
f(x)=(x-1)(x-2) \cdots(x-p+1), \\
g(x)=x^{p-1}-1 .
\end{array}
$$

By Fermat's Little Theorem, we know
$$
f(k) \equiv g(k)(\bmod p)(1 \leqslant k \leqslant p-1) \text {. }
$$

But $f(x)-g(x)$ is a polynomial of degree not exceeding $p-2$, so $f(x) \equiv g(x)(\bmod p)$.
By comparing coefficients, we can obtain the lemma.
Now, we prove the original problem.
$$
\mathrm{C}_{2 p}^{p}-2=\frac{2}{(p-1)!}(f(2 p)-f(p))
$$

When $p \geqslant 5$, we have
$$
f(p)=p^{p-1}-\sigma_{1} p^{p-2}+\cdots-\sigma_{p-2} p+(p-1)!
$$

Taking modulo $p^{3}$ on both sides and noting that $f(p)=(p-1)!$, we get
$$
p^{2} \mid \sigma_{p-2} \text {. }
$$

Thus, from $f(2 p)=(2 p)^{p-1}-\sigma_{1}(2 p)^{p-2}+$ $\cdots-2 \sigma_{p-2} p+f(p)$, we get
$$
f(2 p)-f(p) \equiv 0\left(\bmod p^{3}\right) .
$$

From this and $(p,(p-1)!)=1$, we know $p^{3} \mid\left(\mathrm{C}_{2 p}^{p}-2\right)$.
Therefore, $p^{3} \mid \sum_{k=1}^{p-1}\left(\mathrm{C}_{p}^{k}\right)^{2}(p \geqslant 5)$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 223 Let $p$ be a prime. Prove:
(1) For all primes $p (p \geqslant 2), p^{2} \mid \sum_{k=1}^{p-1}\left(\mathrm{C}_{p}^{k}\right)^{2}$;
(2) For all primes $p (p \geqslant 5), p^{3} \mid \sum_{k=1}^{p-1}\left(\mathrm{C}_{p}^{k}\right)^{2}$. -/
theorem number_theory_325890 {p : ℕ} (hp : Nat.Prime p) :
    (2 ≤ p → p^2 ∣ ∑ k in Finset.Icc 1 (p - 1), (Nat.choose p k)^2) ∧
    (5 ≤ p → p^3 ∣ ∑ k in Finset.Icc 1 (p - 1), (Nat.choose p k)^2) := by

soln_description:
Answer: 26789.

Solution. For a four-digit number with different digits, the maximum possible sum of digits is $9+8+7+6=30<32$, so the number we need must be at least five digits.

We will try to make the first digit as small as possible. It is clear that it is no less than 2. We will place 2 in the first position. The sum of the remaining four digits is 30, which can only be obtained as $9+8+7+6$. We place the smallest of these digits, 6, in the second position, the next largest digit, 7, in the third position, 8 in the fourth, and 9 in the fifth.
informal_statement: Task 4.2. Find the smallest number in which all digits are different, and the sum of all digits is 32.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Task 4.2. Find the smallest number in which all digits are different, and the sum of all digits is 32. -/
theorem number_theory_129318 :
    IsLeast {n | (Nat.digits 10 n).length = 5 ∧ (Nat.digits 10 n).toFinset.card = 5 ∧ (Nat.digits 10 n).sum = 32} 26789 := by

soln_description:
## Solution

$$
\int_{-1}^{0}(x+2)^{3} \cdot \ln ^{2}(x+2) d x=
$$

Let's denote:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& u=\ln ^{2}(x+2) ; d u=2 \ln (x+2) \cdot \frac{1}{x+2} \cdot d x \\
& d v=(x+2)^{3} \cdot d x ; v=\frac{(x+2)^{4}}{4}
\end{aligned}
$$

Using the integration by parts formula $\int u d v=u v-\int v d u$, we get:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\left.\ln ^{2}(x+2) \cdot \frac{(x+2)^{4}}{4}\right|_{-1} ^{0}-\int_{-1}^{0} \frac{(x+2)^{4}}{4} \cdot 2 \ln (x+2) \cdot \frac{1}{x+2} \cdot d x= \\
& =\ln ^{2}(0+2) \cdot \frac{(0+2)^{4}}{4}-\ln ^{2}(-1+2) \cdot \frac{(-1+2)^{4}}{4}-\frac{1}{2} \cdot \int_{-1}^{0}(x+2)^{3} \cdot \ln (x+2) \cdot d x= \\
& =4 \ln ^{2} 2-0 \cdot \frac{1^{4}}{4}-\frac{1}{2} \cdot \int_{-1}^{0}(x+2)^{3} \cdot \ln (x+2) \cdot d x=4 \ln ^{2} 2-\frac{1}{2} \cdot \int_{-1}^{0}(x+2)^{3} \cdot \ln (x+2) \cdot d x=
\end{aligned}
$$

Let's denote:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& u=\ln (x+2) ; d u=\frac{1}{x+2} d x \\
& d v=(x+2)^{3} \cdot d x ; v=\frac{(x+2)^{4}}{4}
\end{aligned}
$$

Using the integration by parts formula $\int u d v=u v-\int v d u$, we get:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =4 \ln ^{2} 2-\frac{1}{2} \cdot\left(\left.\ln (x+2) \cdot \frac{(x+2)^{4}}{4}\right|_{-1} ^{0}-\int_{-1}^{0} \frac{(x+2)^{4}}{4} \cdot \frac{1}{x+2} d x\right)= \\
& =4 \ln ^{2} 2-\frac{1}{2} \cdot\left(\ln (0+2) \cdot \frac{(0+2)^{4}}{4}-\ln (-1+2) \cdot \frac{(-1+2)^{4}}{4}-\frac{1}{4} \int_{-1}^{0}(x+2)^{3} \cdot d x\right)= \\
& =4 \ln ^{2} 2-\frac{1}{2} \cdot\left(4 \ln 2-0 \cdot \frac{1^{4}}{4}-\left.\frac{1}{4} \cdot \frac{(x+2)^{4}}{4}\right|_{-1} ^{0}\right)=4 \ln ^{2} 2-\frac{1}{2} \cdot\left(4 \ln 2-\frac{(0+2)^{4}}{16}+\frac{(-1+2)^{4}}{16}\right)=
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =4 \ln ^{2} 2-\frac{1}{2} \cdot\left(4 \ln 2-1+\frac{1}{16}\right)=4 \ln ^{2} 2-2 \ln 2+\frac{1}{2}-\frac{1}{32}= \\
& =4 \ln ^{2} 2-2 \ln 2+\frac{15}{32}
\end{aligned}
$$

/- ## Problem Statement

Calculate the definite integral:

$$
\int_{-1}^{0}(x+2)^{3} \cdot \ln ^{2}(x+2) d x
$$ -/
theorem calculus_150520 : ∫ x in (-1)..0, (x + 2)^3 * (log (x + 2))^2 = 4 * (log 2)^2 - 2 * log 2 + 15 / 32 := by

informal_statement:
Let $a$ and $b$ be real numbers satisfying $a>b>0$. Evaluate

$$
\int_{0}^{2 \pi} \frac{1}{a+b \cos (\theta)} d \theta
$$

Express your answer in terms of $a$ and $b$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- Let $a$ and $b$ be real numbers satisfying $a>b>0$. Evaluate

$$
\int_{0}^{2 \pi} \frac{1}{a+b \cos (\theta)} d \theta
$$

Express your answer in terms of $a$ and $b$. -/
theorem calculus_608482 (a b : ℝ) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) (hab : a > b) :
    ∫ t in Set.Icc 0 (2 * π), 1 / (a + b * cos t) = 2 * π / sqrt (a^2 - b^2) := by

soln_description:
The required inequality is satisfied if and only if the two inequalities

$$
\frac{11}{15}0$ and the inequality $15 x>77$ is satisfied. This is true if and only if $x>\frac{77}{15}$, which, since $\frac{77}{15}=5 \frac{2}{15}$, is satisfied precisely by the natural numbers $x$ with $x \geq 6$.

Thus, the validity of (1) and (2) for natural numbers $x$ is equivalent to $6 \leq x \leq 9$ (i.e., the numbers sought are exactly the numbers 6, 7, 8, and 9).
informal_statement:
## Task 3 - 240823

Determine all natural numbers $x$ that satisfy the inequality

$$
\frac{11}{15}<\frac{7}{x}<\frac{15}{11} \quad \text { ! }
$$
informal_proof:
We want to prove that the inequality `(11/15 < 7/x) ∧ (7/x < 15/11)` holds if and only if `x` is one of the natural numbers `6, 7, 8,` or `9`. We prove this equivalence by showing both implications.

**Part 1: Forward Implication (If `11/15 < 7/x < 15/11`, then `x ∈ {6, 7, 8, 9}`)**

Assume that `(11/15 < 7/x)` (let's call this `h₁`) and `(7/x < 15/11)` (let's call this `h₂`).

1.  **Show that `x` must be positive:**
    We proceed by contradiction. Suppose `x` is not greater than zero. Since `x` is a natural number, this implies `x = 0`. If `x = 0`, then the expressions `7/x` in `h₁` and `h₂` involve division by zero, which is undefined in real numbers. This contradicts the assumption that the inequalities `h₁` and `h₂` hold. Thus, `x` must be strictly greater than zero.

2.  **Derive an upper bound for `x` from `h₁`:**
    We use the inequality `h₁ : 11/15 < 7/x`. Since we know `x > 0`, we can multiply both sides by `15x` (which is a positive quantity) without changing the direction of the inequality. This yields:
    `11 * x < 7 * 15`
    `11x < 105`
    Now, we show by contradiction that `x` must be less than or equal to `9`. Suppose `x` is strictly greater than `9`. Since `x` is a natural number, this means `x ≥ 10`. If `x ≥ 10`, then `11x ≥ 11 * 10 = 110`.
    Combining `11x ≥ 110` with `11x < 105`, we get `110 < 105`, which is a contradiction. Therefore, our assumption that `x > 9` must be false, meaning `x ≤ 9`.

3.  **Derive a lower bound for `x` from `h₂`:**
    We use the inequality `h₂ : 7/x < 15/11`. Again, since `x > 0`, we can multiply both sides by `11x` (a positive quantity) to get:
    `7 * 11 < 15 * x`
    `77 < 15x`
    Now, we show by contradiction that `x` must be greater than or equal to `6`. Suppose `x` is strictly less than `6`. Since `x` is a natural number, this means `x` can be `0, 1, 2, 3, 4,` or `5`.
    *   We already established that `x > 0`, so `x = 0` is not possible.
    *   Let's check the remaining possibilities:
        *   If `x = 1`, `7/1 = 7`. Is `7 < 15/11`? No, `7` is much larger than `15/11 ≈ 1.36`. This contradicts `h₂`.
        *   If `x = 2`, `7/2 = 3.5`. Is `3.5 < 15/11`? No. This contradicts `h₂`.
        *   If `x = 3`, `7/3 ≈ 2.33`. Is `2.33 < 15/11`? No. This contradicts `h₂`.
        *   If `x = 4`, `7/4 = 1.75`. Is `1.75 < 15/11`? No. This contradicts `h₂`.
        *   If `x = 5`, `7/5 = 1.4`. Is `1.4 < 15/11`? No, `1.4 ≈ 15.4/11`. This contradicts `h₂`.
    Since assuming `x < 6` leads to a contradiction in all possible cases, our assumption must be false. Therefore, `x ≥ 6`.

4.  **Combine the bounds:**
    From steps 2 and 3, we have `x ≤ 9` and `x ≥ 6`. Since `x` is a natural number, the possible values for `x` are `6, 7, 8,` or `9`.

**Part 2: Reverse Implication (If `x ∈ {6, 7, 8, 9}`, then `11/15 < 7/x < 15/11`)**

We now assume that `x` is one of `6, 7, 8,` or `9`, and we must show that the compound inequality holds for each case.

1.  **Case `x = 6`:**
    We need to check `11/15 < 7/6` and `7/6 < 15/11`.
    *   `11/15 ≈ 0.733...`
    *   `7/6 ≈ 1.166...`
    *   `15/11 ≈ 1.363...`
    The inequalities become `0.733... < 1.166...` (true) and `1.166... < 1.363...` (true). Both are true.

2.  **Case `x = 7`:**
    We need to check `11/15 < 7/7` and `7/7 < 15/11`.
    *   `11/15 ≈ 0.733...`
    *   `7/7 = 1`
    *   `15/11 ≈ 1.363...`
    The inequalities become `0.733... < 1` (true) and `1 < 1.363...` (true). Both are true.

3.  **Case `x = 8`:**
    We need to check `11/15 < 7/8` and `7/8 < 15/11`.
    *   `11/15 ≈ 0.733...`
    *   `7/8 = 0.875`
    *   `15/11 ≈ 1.363...`
    The inequalities become `0.733... < 0.875` (true) and `0.875 < 1.363...` (true). Both are true.

4.  **Case `x = 9`:**
    We need to check `11/15 < 7/9` and `7/9 < 15/11`.
    *   `11/15 ≈ 0.733...`
    *   `7/9 ≈ 0.777...`
    *   `15/11 ≈ 1.363...`
    The inequalities become `0.733... < 0.777...` (true) and `0.777... < 1.363...` (true). Both are true.

Since the inequality holds for all possible values of `x` in the set `{6, 7, 8, 9}`, the reverse implication is proven.

**Conclusion:**
Both directions of the equivalence have been proven. Therefore, the given inequality holds if and only if `x` is `6, 7, 8,` or `9`.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- ## Task 3 - 240823

Determine all natural numbers $x$ that satisfy the inequality

$$
\frac{11}{15}<\frac{7}{x}<\frac{15}{11} \quad \text { ! }
$$ -/
theorem inequalities_174554 (x : ℕ) :
    (11 / 15 : ℝ) < (7 / x : ℝ) ∧ (7 / x : ℝ) < (15 / 11 : ℝ) ↔
    x = 6 ∨ x = 7 ∨ x = 8 ∨ x = 9 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem inequalities_174554 (x : ℕ) :
    (11 / 15 : ℝ) < (7 / x : ℝ) ∧ (7 / x : ℝ) < (15 / 11 : ℝ) ↔
    x = 6 ∨ x = 7 ∨ x = 8 ∨ x = 9 := by
  constructor
  · -- Forward direction: If the inequality holds, then x is in the set
    intro h
    rcases h with ⟨h₁, h₂⟩
    -- Show that x > 0
    have hx1 : x > 0 := by
      by_contra h'
      push_neg at h'
      have h'1 : x = 0 := by omega
      rw [h'1] at h₁ h₂
      norm_num at h₁ h₂
    -- From left inequality: 11/15 < 7/x
    have h3 : x ≤ 9 := by
      by_contra h'
      push_neg at h'
      have hx2 : (x : ℝ) > 0 := by exact_mod_cast (show x > 0 by linarith)
      have h4 : (x : ℝ) ≥ (10 : ℝ) := by
        have h5 : x ≥ 10 := by omega
        exact_mod_cast h5
      -- Show contradiction
      have h6 : (11 / 15 : ℝ) < (7 / (x : ℝ)) := h₁
      have h7 : (x : ℝ) ≥ (10 : ℝ) := by linarith
      -- Multiply both sides by 15 * x
      have h8 : (11 : ℝ) * (x : ℝ) < (105 : ℝ) := by
        have h9 : (7 / (x : ℝ) : ℝ) > (11 / 15 : ℝ) := by linarith
        have h10 : (x : ℝ) > (0 : ℝ) := by nlinarith [h9]
        have h11 : (7 / (x : ℝ) : ℝ) = (7 : ℝ) / (x : ℝ) := by ring
        have h12 : (11 / 15 : ℝ) = (11 : ℝ) / 15 := by ring
        rw [h11, h12] at h9
        apply (div_lt_div_iff (by positivity) (by positivity)).mp at h9
        nlinarith
      nlinarith
    -- From right inequality: 7/x < 15/11
    have h5 : x ≥ 6 := by
      by_contra h'
      push_neg at h'
      have hx3 : x ≤ 5 := by omega
      interval_cases x <;> norm_num at h₁ h₂ <;> try { contradiction }
      <;> norm_num at h₁ h₂ <;> tauto
    -- Combine the inequalities
    have h8 : x = 6 ∨ x = 7 ∨ x = 8 ∨ x = 9 := by
      omega
    exact h8
  · -- Reverse direction: If x is in the set, then the inequality holds
    rintro (rfl | rfl | rfl | rfl)
    · constructor
      · norm_num
      · norm_num
    · constructor
      · norm_num
      · norm_num
    · constructor
      · norm_num
      · norm_num
    · constructor
      · norm_num
      · norm_num

soln_description:
Analysis and Solution According to the problem, there exists $k \in \mathbf{N}$, such that
$$
a b c-1=k(a-1)(b-1)(c-1)
$$

By the discreteness of integers, we have $a \leqslant b-1, a \leqslant c-2$,
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\text { Hence }(k-1)(a-1)(b-1)(c-1)=(a b c-1)-(a-1)(b-1)(c-1) \\
\quad=a b+b c+c a-a-b-c=a(b-1)+b(c-1)+c(a-1) \\
\quad \leqslant(c-2)(b-1)+b(c-1)+c(b-2)=3(b c-b-c+1)-1 \\
\quad0$, so $k \neq 1$, hence $(k-1) \cdot(a-1)=1$ or $(k-1)(a-1)=2$.
(1) If $(k-1)(a-1)=1$ holds, then $k=a=2$. At this time, the left side of (1) is odd, and the right side is even, which is a contradiction.
(2) If $(k-1)(a-1)=2$ holds, then $a=3, k=2$

or $a=2, k=3$
Substituting (2) into (1), we get $3 b c-1=4(b-1)(c-1)=4(b c-b-c+1)$, i.e., $b c-4(b+c)+16=11$, i.e., $(b-4)(c-4)=11$.
Also, since $c>b$, we have $b-4=1, c-4=11$,
so $b=5, c=15$.
Similarly, substituting (3) into (1) yields $b=4, c=8$.
Upon verification, we get $a=3, b=5, c=15$, or $a=2, b=4, c=8$.
informal_statement:
Example 10 Try to find all positive integers $a, b, c$, where $1<a<b<c$, and such that $(a-1)(b-1)(c-1)$ is a divisor of $a b c-1$.

Find all positive integers $a, b, c$, where $1<a<b<c$, and such that $(a-1)(b-1)(c-1)$ is a divisor of $a b c-1$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Example 10 Try to find all positive integers $a, b, c$, where $1<a<b<c$, and such that $(a-1)(b-1)(c-1)$ is a divisor of $a b c-1$.

Find all positive integers $a, b, c$, where $1<a<b<c$, and such that $(a-1)(b-1)(c-1)$ is a divisor of $a b c-1$. -/
theorem number_theory_201691 (a b c : ℕ) (ha : 1 < a) (hb : a < b) (hc : b < c)
    (h : (a - 1) * (b - 1) * (c - 1) ∣ a * b * c - 1) :
    (a = 3 ∧ b = 5 ∧ c = 15) ∨ (a = 2 ∧ b = 4 ∧ c = 8) := by

soln_description:
11. The largest constant $C$ is $\frac{\sqrt{3}}{3}$.

Consider the interesting complex sequence $\left\{z_{n}\right\}$.
By induction, we know $z_{n} \neq 0\left(n \in \mathbf{Z}_{+}\right)$.
From the condition, we have
$$
\begin{array}{l}
4\left(\frac{z_{n+1}}{z_{n}}\right)^{2}+2\left(\frac{z_{n+1}}{z_{n}}\right)+1=0\left(n \in \mathbf{Z}_{+}\right) \\
\Rightarrow \frac{z_{n+1}}{z_{n}}=\frac{-1 \pm \sqrt{3} \mathrm{i}}{4}\left(n \in \mathbf{Z}_{+}\right) \\
\Rightarrow \frac{\left|z_{n+1}\right|}{\left|z_{n}\right|}=\left|\frac{z_{n+1}}{z_{n}}\right|=\left|\frac{-1 \pm \sqrt{3} \mathrm{i}}{4}\right|=\frac{1}{2} \\
\Rightarrow\left|z_{n}\right|=\left|z_{1}\right| \frac{1}{2^{n-1}}=\frac{1}{2^{n-1}}\left(n \in \mathbf{Z}_{+}\right) .
\end{array}
$$

Thus, $\left|z_{n}+z_{n+1}\right|=\left|z_{n}\right|\left|1+\frac{z_{n+1}}{z_{n}}\right|$
$$
=\frac{1}{2^{n-1}}\left|\frac{3 \pm \sqrt{3} i}{4}\right|=\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2^{n}}\left(n \in \mathbf{Z}_{+}\right) \text {. }
$$

Let $T_{m}=\left|z_{1}+z_{2}+\cdots+z_{m}\right|\left(m \in \mathbf{Z}_{+}\right)$.
When $m=2 s\left(s \in \mathbf{Z}_{+}\right)$, using equation (2), we get
$$
\begin{array}{l}
T_{m} \geqslant\left|z_{1}+z_{2}\right|-\sum_{k=2}^{s}\left|z_{2 k-1}+z_{2 k}\right| \\
>\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}-\sum_{k=2}^{\infty}\left|z_{2 k-1}+z_{2 k}\right| \\
=\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}-\sum_{k=2}^{\infty} \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2^{2 k-1}}=\frac{\sqrt{3}}{3} .
\end{array}
$$

When $m=2 s+1\left(s \in \mathbf{Z}_{+}\right)$, from equations (1) and (2), we have
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\left|z_{2 s+1}\right|=\frac{1}{2^{2 s}}\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}-\sum_{k=2}^{\infty}\left|z_{2 k-1}+z_{2 k}\right|=\frac{\sqrt{3}}{3} \text {. }
\end{array}
$$

When $m=1$, $T_{1}=\left|z_{1}\right|=1>\frac{\sqrt{3}}{3}$.
The above shows that $C=\frac{\sqrt{3}}{3}$ meets the requirement.
Furthermore, when $z_{1}=1, z_{2 k}=\frac{-1+\sqrt{3} \mathrm{i}}{2^{2 k}}$,
$$
z_{2 k+1}=\frac{-1-\sqrt{3} \mathrm{i}}{2^{2 k+1}}\left(k \in \mathbf{Z}_{+}\right)
$$

it is easy to verify that $\left\{z_{n}\right\}$ is an interesting sequence. At this time,
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\lim _{s \rightarrow \infty} T_{2 s+1}=\lim _{s \rightarrow \infty}\left|z_{1}+\sum_{k=1}^{s}\left(z_{2 k}+z_{2 k+1}\right)\right| \\
=\lim _{s \rightarrow \infty}\left|1+\sum_{k=1}^{s} \frac{-3-\sqrt{3} \mathrm{i}}{2^{2 k+1}}\right| \\
=\left|1+\frac{-3+\sqrt{3} \mathrm{i}}{8} \cdot \frac{4}{3}\right|=\frac{\sqrt{3}}{3},
\end{array}
$$

This shows that $C$ cannot be greater than $\frac{\sqrt{3}}{3}$.
In summary, the required $C$ is $\frac{\sqrt{3}}{3}$.
informal_statement:
11. (20 points) A sequence of complex numbers $\left\{z_{n}\right\}$ is called "interesting" if $\left|z_{1}\right|=1$, and for any positive integer $n$, we have
$$
4 z_{n+1}^{2}+2 z_{n} z_{n+1}+z_{n}^{2}=0 \text {. }
$$

Find the largest constant $C$ such that for all interesting sequences $\left\{z_{n}\right\}$ and any positive integer $m$, we have
$$
\left|z_{1}+z_{2}+\cdots+z_{m}\right| \geqslant C \text {. }
$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Complex Filter Function Metric Finset
open scoped BigOperators Topology

/- 11. (20 points) A sequence of complex numbers $\left\{z_{n}\right\}$ is called "interesting" if $\left|z_{1}\right|=1$, and for any positive integer $n$, we have
$$
4 z_{n+1}^{2}+2 z_{n} z_{n+1}+z_{n}^{2}=0 \text {. }
$$

Find the largest constant $C$ such that for all interesting sequences $\left\{z_{n}\right\}$ and any positive integer $m$, we have
$$
\left|z_{1}+z_{2}+\cdots+z_{m}\right| \geqslant C \text {. }
$$ -/
theorem algebra_103863 {C : ℝ} (hC : ∀ z : ℕ → ℂ, (∀ n, 0 < n → 4 * (z (n + 1))^2 + 2 * z n * z (n + 1) + (z n)^2 = 0) ∧
    ‖z 1‖ = 1 → ‖∑ i in Icc 1 m, z i‖ ≥ C) :
    C ≤ Real.sqrt 3 / 3 := by

soln_description:
5. The answer is $x=420$.

Let $p_{1}, p_{2}-p_{1}, \ldots$ be all the primes arranged in increasing order. By Bertrand' $\&$ Postulate, we have $p_{i}p_{k-1}^{3}$.
Let $p_{k} \leq \sqrt[1]{x}2^{3}$ and $11>3^{2}$, we have $2^{3} 3^{2} \mid x$. Since $k \geq 5, \operatorname{gcd}\left(p_{k} p_{k-1} p_{k} \cdot 2 \cdot 2^{3} 3^{2}\right)=1$ and thus $2^{3} 3^{2} p_{k} p_{k-1} p_{k-2} \mid x$. This means we have $x \geq 72 p_{k} p_{k-1} p_{k-2}>64 p_{k} p_{k-1} p_{k-2}>p_{k+1}^{3}$, implying $p_{k+1}7$. It then follows that $x$ is divisible by $2^{2} \cdot 3 \cdot 5 \cdot 7=420$.
Finally, suppose $\sqrt[3]{x} \geq 9$. We theu have $2^{3} \cdot 3^{2} \cdot 5 \cdot 7 \mid x$, i.c., $x \geq 2^{3} \cdot 3^{2} \cdot 5 \cdot 7=2520$, which is a contradiction since $x<1331$. Tluts $\sqrt[3]{x}<9$. or $x<729$. Since $420 \mid x$ aud $x<729$. we have $x=420$.
Alternatively. since $x<1331$ and $420 \mid x$, we only need to check the cases $x=$ 420.840 .1260 .
informal_statement: 5. Find the largest positive integer $x$ such that $x$ is divisible by all the positive integers $\leq \sqrt[3]{x}$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 5. Find the largest positive integer $x$ such that $x$ is divisible by all the positive integers $\leq \sqrt[3]{x}$. -/
theorem number_theory_285427 :
    IsGreatest {x | 0 < x ∧ ∀ i ∈ Finset.Icc 1 ⌊(x : ℝ) ^ ((1 : ℝ) / 3)⌋₊, x % i = 0} 420 := by

soln_description:
Let the positive divisors of $N$ be $d_{1}, d_{2}, \cdots, d_{k}$, and $1=d_{1}<d_{2}<\cdots<d_{k}=N$. Then
$$
\sum_{i=1}^{k} d_{i}^{2}=N(N+3).
$$

Thus, $d_{2}^{2}+d_{3}^{2}+\cdots+d_{k-1}^{2}=3 N-1$.
Notice that, $d_{i} d_{k+1-i}=N$.
Then $3 N-1=\frac{1}{2} \sum_{i=2}^{k-1}\left(d_{i}^{2}+d_{k+1-i}^{2}\right)$
$$
\geqslant \frac{1}{2} \sum_{i=2}^{k-1} 2 N=(k-2) N.
$$

Hence $k<5$.
If $k=1$, then $N=1,1^{2}=1 \times(1+3)$, which is a contradiction.
If $k=2$, then $N=p$ (where $p$ is a prime),
$$
1^{2}+p^{2}=p(p+3) \Rightarrow 3 p=1,
$$

which is a contradiction.
If $k=3$, then $N=p^{2}$ (where $p$ is a prime),
$$
1^{2}+p^{2}+p^{4}=p^{2}\left(p^{2}+3\right) \Rightarrow 1=2 p^{2},
$$

which is a contradiction.
Thus, $k=4$, then
$N=p^{3}$ or $N=p q$ (where $p, q$ are primes, and $p \neq q$).
If $N=p^{3}$, then
$$
\begin{array}{l}
1^{2}+p^{2}+p^{4}+p^{6}=p^{3}\left(p^{3}+3\right) \\
\Rightarrow 1+p^{2}+p^{4}=3 p^{3}, p \mid 1,
\end{array}
$$

which is a contradiction.
Therefore, $N=p q$, then
$$
\begin{array}{l}
1^{2}+p^{2}+q^{2}+p^{2} q^{2}=p q(p q+3) \\
\Rightarrow p^{2}+q^{2}=3 p q-1 .
\end{array}
$$

It suffices to prove: For each solution $(p, q)(p<q)$ of equation (1), there exist indices $i, j(i<j)$ such that
$$
F_{i}=p, F_{j}=q.
$$

We prove a stronger conclusion: For each solution $(a, b)$ $(a<b$ and not necessarily primes) of equation (1), there exist indices $2 i-1$ and $2 i+1$ such that
$$
a=F_{2 i-1}, b=F_{2 i+1}.
$$

Proof by contradiction.
If the above conclusion does not hold, i.e., there exists a solution $(a, b)(a<b)$ of equation (1) such that for any $i \in \mathbf{Z}_{+}$, we have $\{a, b\} \neq\left\{F_{2 i-1}, F_{2 i+1}\right\}$.
Let $\left(a_{0}, b_{0}\right)$ be the solution that:
(1) $a<b$;
(2) $a^{2}+b^{2}=3 a b-1$;
(3) For any $i$, we have
$$
\{a, b\} \neq\left\{F_{2 i-1}, F_{2 i+1}\right\}.
$$

By (2), we know that $b_{0}$ is an integer solution of the equation
$$
x^{2}-3 x a_{0}+a_{0}^{2}+1=0.
$$

Let $b_{0}^{\prime}$ be the other solution of this equation. Then
$$
b_{0}+b_{0}^{\prime}=3 a_{0}.
$$

Thus, $b_{0}^{\prime} \in \mathbf{Z}$ (if $a_{0}=1$, then $b_{0}=1$ or 2, which contradicts (3). Hence $a_{0} \neq 1$), and $b_{0}^{\prime}=\frac{a_{0}^{2}+1}{b_{0}}$.
By $a_{0}<b_{0}$, we know $b_{0}^{\prime}<a_{0}$, and $b_{0}^{\prime} \in \mathbf{Z}_{+}$.
Thus, $\left(b_{0}^{\prime}, a_{0}\right)$ is also a solution of equation (1), and $b_{0}^{\prime}+a_{0}<a_{0}+b_{0}$.
By the minimality, there exists $i$ such that
$b_{0}^{\prime}=F_{2 i-1}, a_{0}=F_{2 i+1}$.
Then $b_{0}=3 a_{0}-b_{0}^{\prime}=3 F_{2 i+1}-F_{2 i-1}$
$=2 F_{2 i+1}+F_{2 i}=F_{2 i+1}+F_{2 i+2}=F_{2 i+3}$.
Hence $\left(a_{0}, b_{0}\right)=\left(F_{2 i+1}, F_{2 i+3}\right)$, which contradicts (3).
Thus, the conclusion (2) is proved, and the original proposition holds.
informal_statement: Four. (50 points) Let $N$ be a positive integer such that the sum of the squares of all positive divisors of $N$ is exactly equal to $N(N+3)$. Prove: there exist two indices $i, j$ such that $N=F_{i} \cdot F_{j}$, where $\left\{F_{n}\right\}(n \geqslant 1)$ is the Fibonacci sequence.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Four. (50 points) Let $N$ be a positive integer such that the sum of the squares of all positive divisors of $N$ is exactly equal to $N(N+3)$. Prove: there exist two indices $i, j$ such that $N=F_{i} \cdot F_{j}$, where $\left\{F_{n}\right\}(n \geqslant 1)$ is the Fibonacci sequence. -/
theorem number_theory_266102 {N : ℕ} (hN : N > 0) (h : ∑ d in N.divisors, d^2 = N * (N + 3)) :
    ∃ i j, N = Nat.fib i * Nat.fib j := by

soln_description:
1. We start with the given inequality:
   \[
   \sum_{i=1}^{n}\sum_{j=1}^{n}(n-|i-j|)x_ix_j \geq c\sum_{j=1}^{n}x^2_i
   \]
   We need to find the largest real number \( c \) such that this inequality holds for any positive integer \( n \) and any real numbers \( x_1, x_2, \ldots, x_n \).

2. Let \( s = \sum_{i=1}^{n} x_i \). We introduce the notation \( y_k = \frac{1}{2} \left( -\sum_{l=1}^{k} x_l + \sum_{l=k+1}^{n} x_l \right) \) with \( y_0 = -y_n = \frac{s}{2} \).

3. We rewrite the left-hand side of the inequality:
   \[
   \sum_{i,j}(n-|i-j|)x_ix_j = s^2 + \sum_{k=1}^{n-1} \left( \left( \sum_{l=1}^{k} x_l \right)^2 + \left( \sum_{l=k+1}^{n} x_l \right)^2 \right)
   \]

4. Using the definition of \( y_k \), we can express the sum as:
   \[
   s^2 + \sum_{k=1}^{n-1} \left( 2y_k^2 + \frac{s^2}{2} \right) = \frac{n-1}{2}s^2 + \sum_{k=1}^{n} (y_{k-1}^2 + y_k^2)
   \]

5. We know that:
   \[
   \sum_{k=1}^{n} (y_{k-1}^2 + y_k^2) \geq 0 + \frac{1}{2} \sum_{k=1}^{n} (y_{k-1} - y_k)^2 = \frac{1}{2} \sum_{k=1}^{n} x_k^2
   \]

6. Therefore, we have:
   \[
   \sum_{i,j}(n-|i-j|)x_ix_j \geq \frac{1}{2} \sum_{k=1}^{n} x_k^2
   \]

7. This implies that the largest value of \( c \) is \( \frac{1}{2} \).

The final answer is \( \boxed{\frac{1}{2}} \).
informal_statement:
Find  the largest real number $c$ such that $$\sum_{i=1}^{n}\sum_{j=1}^{n}(n-|i-j|)x_ix_j \geq c\sum_{j=1}^{n}x^2_i$$
for  any positive integer $n $ and  any real numbers $x_1,x_2,\dots,x_n.$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- Find  the largest real number $c$ such that $$\sum_{i=1}^{n}\sum_{j=1}^{n}(n-|i-j|)x_ix_j \geq c\sum_{j=1}^{n}x^2_i$$
for  any positive integer $n $ and  any real numbers $x_1,x_2,\dots,x_n.$ -/
theorem inequalities_43542 (c : ℝ) :
    (∀ n : ℕ, 0 < n → ∀ x : Fin n → ℝ,
      ∑ i : Fin n, ∑ j : Fin n, (n - |(i.1 : ℤ) - j.1|) * x i * x j ≥
        c * ∑ i : Fin n, (x i)^2) ↔ c ≤ 1 / 2 := by

10 a^{2}-3 a b+7 c^{2}=0 \text {. }

import Mathlib

/- 1. Given positive integers $a, b, c$ satisfy
$$
10 a^{2}-3 a b+7 c^{2}=0 \text {. }

Find the minimum value of $(a, b)(b, c)(c, a)$. -/
theorem number_theory_198648 (a b c : ℤ) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) (hc : 0 < c)
    (h : 10 * a ^ 2 - 3 * a * b + 7 * c ^ 2 = 0) :
    a.gcd b * b.gcd c * c.gcd a ≥ 3 := by

informal_statement: 11. Real numbers $t_{1}, t_{2}, \cdots, t_{n}$ are $n$ real numbers, satisfying $0<t_{1} \leqslant t_{2} \leqslant \cdots \leqslant t_{n}<1$, prove: $\left(1-t_{n}\right)^{2}\left[\frac{t_{1}}{\left(1-t_{1}^{2}\right)^{2}}+\frac{t_{2}^{2}}{\left(1-t_{2}^{3}\right)^{2}}+\cdots+\frac{t_{n}^{n}}{\left(1-t_{n}^{n+1}\right)^{2}}\right]<\mathrm{I} . \quad($ 28th IMO Shortlist Problem)
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 11. Real numbers $t_{1}, t_{2}, \cdots, t_{n}$ are $n$ real numbers, satisfying $0<t_{1} \leqslant t_{2} \leqslant \cdots \leqslant t_{n}<1$, prove: $\left(1-t_{n}\right)^{2}\left[\frac{t_{1}}{\left(1-t_{1}^{2}\right)^{2}}+\frac{t_{2}^{2}}{\left(1-t_{2}^{3}\right)^{2}}+\cdots+\frac{t_{n}^{n}}{\left(1-t_{n}^{n+1}\right)^{2}}\right]<\mathrm{I} . \quad($ 28th IMO Shortlist Problem) -/
theorem inequalities_597373 {n : ℕ} (hn : 0 < n) (t : ℕ → ℝ)
    (ht : ∀ i ∈ Icc 1 n, 0 < t i ∧ t i ≤ t (i + 1)) (ht' : t n < 1) :
    (1 - t n) ^ 2 * ∑ i ∈ Icc 1 n, (t i) ^ i / (1 - (t i) ^ (i + 1)) ^ 2 < 1 := by

informal_statement: Solve the equation $(6x+7)^2(3x+4)(x+1)=6$ for $x$. Express all solutions, including any complex roots, in their simplest form.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Solve the equation $(6x+7)^2(3x+4)(x+1)=6$ for $x$. Express all solutions, including any complex roots, in their simplest form. -/
theorem algebra_5371 (x : ℂ) :
    (6 * x + 7) ^ 2 * (3 * x + 4) * (x + 1) = 6 ↔
    x = -5 / 3 ∨ x = -2 / 3 ∨
    x = (-7 - 2 * Complex.I * Real.sqrt 2) / 6 ∨
    x = (-7 + 2 * Complex.I * Real.sqrt 2) / 6 := by
